Award.AwardTitle: Quantitative Characterization of Quark-Gluon Plasma Properties with Dynamical Fluctuations
Award.AbstractNarration: Quantifying the phase structure of matter at extreme temperature and density has profound impacts on understanding how quarks and gluons, the building blocks of nucleons, interact collectively and elucidating the property of the early Universe within the first microsecond after its creation in the Big Bang. High energy collisions of atomic nuclei create the Quark-Gluon Plasma (QGP), a new state of matter at about 2 trillion degrees Kelvin. The QGP behaves like a nearly perfect fluid, which flows ten times better than water. This project will develop a new theoretical framework to model how small ripples evolve in the QGP fluid. By decoding these ripples' traces in the experimental measurements, the PI will quantify the QGP properties and identify whether the nature of phase transition from ordinary matter to the QGP is like water transits to vapor. This project interweaves nuclear physics, high-performance computing, and advanced machine learning techniques. The interdisciplinary nature of the project helps the participating students acquire solid training in theoretical physics as well as computational science skills.<br/><br/>This project will develop the first theoretical framework to model the 3D dynamical evolution of stochastic fluctuations in relativistic heavy-ion collisions. By studying how fluctuations of energy, momentum, and charge density dissipate in the collision system, one can quantify the thermal, critical, and transport properties of the QGP using experimental measurements. By integrating the proposed framework with the Bayesian analysis and applying them to heavy-ion collisions over wide ranges of collision energies, the PI and his group will extract quantitative phenomenological constraints on the QGP properties. Searching the critical point signature in experimental data is slated to break new ground in the application of deep learning techniques to physical science. This proposed framework serves as an essential infrastructure to guide and interpret the experiments at Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider Beam Energy Scan phase II, and high luminosity runs at the Large Hadron Collider. The theoretical advancement in understanding the dynamics of such a strongly-coupled many-body system can generate interesting cross-talk with cold atomic physics, cosmology, and neutron star/black mergers.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
High energy collisions of heavy nuclei create extreme conditions to study the many-body properties of nuclear matter. Exceeding a temperature of 1.5 trillion degrees Kelvin, the two strongly interacting nuclei are compressed to a new state of matter that exhibits quarks' and gluons' degrees of freedom, the Quark-Gluon Plasma (QGP). The QGP behaves as a nearly perfect liquid emerging from many-body effects of quarks and gluons whose interactions are governed by Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD). This hot and dense soup of elementary particles filled our universe a few microseconds after the Big Bang. The current Beam Energy Scan program (BES) at Relativistic Heavy-Ion Collider (RHIC) further probes the phase structure of QCD matter, namely the first order (liquid-vapor) phase boundary between nuclear matter and QGP terminating in a critical point.


This project developed a comprehensive theoretical framework to quantitatively study the QGP properties. This unified (3+1)D dynamic framework plays a central role in understanding the non-trivial longitudinal dynamics at the RHIC Beam Energy Scan program. It provides a theoretical tool to quantify the initial-state baryon stopping and understand the vortical flow structure. This theoretical framework also enables simulating the 3D dynamics of ultra-peripheral nucleus-nucleus collisions, connecting the studies of the collectivity in small systems with the e+A collisions at the future Electron-Ion Collider. Confronting with the upcoming measurements from the RHIC BES phase II, this framework will serve as a cornerstone for the search for the QCD critical point in relativistic heavy-ion collisions.


This theoretical framework bridges fundamental QCD many-body theory and the phenomenology of relativistic heavy-ion collisions.By applying this framework to heavy-ion collisions over wide ranges of collision energies together with advanced statistical analysis, the PI and his group perform quantitative studies of the transport properties of the QCD matter. This research will benefit the current Beam Energy Scan II and upcoming SPHENIX programs at RHIC, high luminosity runs at LHC, and the future Facility for Antiproton and Ion Research (FAIR). 


The proposed project interweaves theoretical many-body nuclear physics, high-performance computing, and advanced machine-learning techniques. The interdisciplinary nature of the project attracted and trained two undergraduate and two high school students to acquire valuable experience in theoretical physics research as well as in computational science skills.


This project is fully open source. All the products from this project are accessible to the public, including the tags on every milestone achieved during the project development. This ensures that all the scientific results can be reproduced by the public independently.
